  <div id="readme" class="readme blob instapaper_body">
    <article class="markdown-body entry-content" itemprop="text"><table data-table-type="yaml-metadata">
  <thead>
  <tr>
  <th>title</th>
  <th>author</th>
  <th>date</th>
  <th>output</th>
  </tr>
  </thead>
  <tbody>
  <tr>
  <td><div>Daily Steps Takes - Data Analysis</div></td>
  <td><div>Faiyaz Hasan</div></td>
  <td><div>June 17, 2016</div></td>
  <td><div>html_document</div></td>
  </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>

<pre lang="{r"><code>knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, cache = FALSE)
</code></pre>
<ol>
<li>Loading the data</li>
</ol>
<hr>
<p>We set the working directory followed by downloading the dataset from its url and unzipping the file to "step_data.csv". The data comes from Roger Pengs <a href="https://github.com/rdpeng/RepData_PeerAssessment1">github account</a>.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>setwd("C:\\Users\\Windows\\Documents\\JHU_Data_Science\\Course_5\\Project_1\\")
url &lt;- "https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/repdata%2Fdata%2Factivity.zip"
destfile &lt;- "step_data.zip"
download.file(url, destfile)
unzip(destfile)
activity &lt;- read.csv("activity.csv", sep = ",")
</code></pre>
<p>The variable names and the structure of the file are given by</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>names(activity)
str(activity)
head(activity[which(!is.na(activity$steps)), ]) # data set with NA rows removed
</code></pre>
<p>The format of the file is ready for analysis. No further processing is required.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Mean of "total number of step taken per day" over all days</li>
</ol>
<hr>
<p>Group the number of steps by date and intervals. Find the total number of steps per day over all days. Note that some of the days such as 2012-10-01 have no steps data. Remove such rows for this part.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>library(reshape2)
activity_melt &lt;- melt(activity[which(!is.na(activity$steps)), ], id.vars = c("date", "interval"))
head(activity_melt)
steps_sum &lt;- dcast(activity_melt, date ~ variable, sum)
head(steps_sum)
</code></pre>
<p>Then we can find the mean of 'total number of steps per day'.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>summary(steps_sum$steps)
</code></pre>
<p>Histogram of the total number of steps taken each day.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>hist(steps_sum$steps, main = "Histogram of total steps taken per day",
     xlab = "Total steps per day", ylab = "Number of days", 
     breaks = 10, col = "steel blue")
abline(v = mean(steps_sum$steps), lty = 1, lwd = 2, col = "red")
abline(v = median(steps_sum$steps), lty = 2, lwd = 2, col = "black")
legend(x = "topright", c("Mean", "Median"), col = c("red", "black"),       lty = c(1, 2), lwd = c(2, 2))
</code></pre>
<p>Equivalent ggplot.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>library(ggplot2)
ggplot(steps_sum, aes(steps)) + geom_histogram(bins = 10)
</code></pre>
<p>Here's a plot showing the trend in total number of steps taken per day over two months.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>library(lubridate)
steps_sum$date &lt;- as.Date(steps_sum$date)
ggplot(steps_sum, aes(date, steps)) + geom_line() +            
        scale_x_date(date_labels = "%b %d") + 
        ylab("Total number of steps")
</code></pre>
<ol start="3">
<li>Average daily activity pattern</li>
</ol>
<hr>
<p>In this section, we make a time series plot (i.e. type = "l") of the 5-minute interval (x-axis) and the average number of steps taken averaged across all days.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>stepsmeaninterval &lt;- dcast(activity_melt, interval ~ variable, mean, na.rm = TRUE)
head(stepsmeaninterval)
plot(stepsmeaninterval$interval, stepsmeaninterval$steps, ty = "l", 
     xlab = "time interval", ylab = "Average steps", main = "Average 
     steps taken over all days vs \n time interval")
</code></pre>
<p>The time interval during which the maximum number of steps is taken is</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>maxsteps_interval &lt;- stepsmeaninterval$interval[which.max(stepsmeaninterval$steps)]
maxsteps_interval
</code></pre>
<ol start="4">
<li>Imputing missing values</li>
</ol>
<hr>
<p>First of all, let us get a sense for the missing values. Are there days with all time intervals reporting NA step values?</p>
<p>We can replace the missing data for a day by the time average over all other days.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>## Impute missing values
activity2 &lt;- split(activity, activity$interval)
activity2 &lt;- lapply(activity2, function(x) {
        x$steps[which(is.na(x$steps))] &lt;- mean(x$steps, na.rm = TRUE)
        return(x)
})
activity2 &lt;- do.call("rbind", activity2)
row.names(activity2) &lt;- NULL

activity2 &lt;- split(activity2, activity2$date)
df &lt;- lapply(activity2, function(x) {
        x$steps[which(is.na(x$steps))] &lt;- mean(x$steps, na.rm = TRUE)
        return(x)
})
activity2 &lt;- do.call("rbind", activity2)
row.names(activity2) &lt;- NULL
head(activity2)
</code></pre>
<p>Assuming that the time intervals form a disjoint partitioning of 24 hrs, i.e. 1 day is found to be erroneous. The time interval for each day corresponds to approximately 40 hours, which refutes the intervals being disjoint.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>library(reshape2)
activity_melt2 &lt;- melt(activity2, id.vars = c("date", "interval"))
steps_sum &lt;- dcast(activity_melt2, date ~ variable, sum, na.rm = TRUE)
head(steps_sum)
</code></pre>
<p>Histogram of the total number of steps taken each day with the imputed missing values.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>hist(steps_sum$steps, main = "Histogram of total steps taken per day", 
     xlab = "Total steps per day", ylab = "Number of days", 
     breaks = 10, col = "steel blue")
abline(v = mean(steps_sum$steps), lty = 1, lwd = 2, col = "red")
abline(v = median(steps_sum$steps), lty = 2, lwd = 2, col = "black")
legend(x = "topright", c("Mean", "Median"), col = c("red", "black"), lty = c(2, 1), lwd = c(2, 2))
</code></pre>
<p>Number of rows with NA values</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>sum(is.na(activity$steps))
sum(is.na(activity$steps))*100/nrow(activity) # Percentage of rows with missing values
</code></pre>
<ol start="5">
<li>Differences in activity patterns: Weekdays vs Weekends</li>
</ol>
<hr>
<p>Create a new column describing if the date is a weekday or weekend.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>library(lubridate)
weekends &lt;- which(weekdays(as.Date(activity2$date)) == "Saturday" |
              weekdays(as.Date(activity2$date)) == "Sunday")
weekdays &lt;- which(weekdays(as.Date(activity2$date)) != "Saturday" &amp;
              weekdays(as.Date(activity2$date)) != "Sunday")
temp &lt;- c(rep("a", length(activity2)))
temp[weekends] &lt;- "weekend"
temp[weekdays] &lt;- "weekday"
length(temp)
names(temp) &lt;- "day"
activity2 &lt;- cbind(activity2, temp)
names(activity2)[4] &lt;- "day"
</code></pre>
<p>Steps taken over each interval averaged across weekday days and weekend days.</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>activity2split &lt;- split(activity2, activity2$day)
stepsmean_interval &lt;- lapply(activity2split, function(x) {
        temp &lt;- aggregate(x$steps, list(x$interval), mean)
        names(temp) &lt;- c("interval", "steps")
        return(temp)
})

## Unsplit stepsmean_interval
stepsmean_interval &lt;- do.call("rbind", stepsmean_interval)
weekdays &lt;- grep("weekday" ,row.names(stepsmean_interval))
weekends &lt;- grep("weekend" ,row.names(stepsmean_interval))
temp &lt;- c(rep("a", length(stepsmean_interval$steps)))
temp[weekdays] &lt;- "weekdays"
temp[weekends] &lt;- "weekends"
stepsmean_interval &lt;- cbind(stepsmean_interval, temp)
row.names(stepsmean_interval) &lt;- NULL
names(stepsmean_interval)[3] &lt;- "day"
head(stepsmean_interval)
tail(stepsmean_interval)

library(ggplot2)
ggplot(stepsmean_interval, aes(interval, steps)) + geom_line() + facet_grid(day ~ .) 
</code></pre>
<p>The mean number of steps taken over the weekdays and weekends.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>stepsdatamelt &lt;- melt(stepsmean_interval, id.vars = c("interval",
                                                      "day"))
dcast(stepsdatamelt, day ~ variable, mean) # Average steps
</code></pre>
